title: Excitement bubbles up on formal bid chatter for SABMiller
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Sep 28, 2015, 19:14 BST - UK Markets closed Excitement bubbles up on formal bid chatter for SABMiller By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 22 minutes ago 29.27 -1.77 
Another torrid trading session wiped 2.5pc off the FTSE 100, as miners felt the most pain following a bearish broker note. 
Brewer SABMiller added some fizz to Britain’s benchmark index, in what was otherwise a torrid trading session for the mining-heavy index. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in the FTSE 100 company bubbled to the top of the index, hitting its highest level since May, amid reports Anheuser-Busch InBev could be just days away from formally submitting a £70bn bid for the British company. 
In what is set to be the biggest deal of the year, the majority of analysts are calling for an offer of £45 per share, which would result in a price tag of over £70bn. However, as investors piled into the stock, amid chatter that a deal that would create a beer behemoth is imminent, a further two brokers revised their target prices. 
Analysts at RBC Capital Markets reckon AB InBev could stretch their offer to £42 per share, warning anything above this level would lead to “value destruction”. 
James Edwardes Jones, of RBC Capital Markets, said: “We have great respect for ABI’s management and if the price demanded by SAB is too rich would like to think they will have the financial discipline to walk away.” 
The broker also believes the only disposals made will be those required by anti-trust authorities, highlighting the takeover will be about “a global domination strategy on the part of ABI”. 
* Anheuser-Busch InBev explores $280bn mega deal for SABMiller (Amsterdam: MI8.AS - news ) * Another takeover challenge for SABMiller’s chairman Separately, Société Générale upgraded the stock to “buy”, lifting its target price by £8 to £43. Analysts said they do not expect it to be a lengthy bid process. However, to succeed in its bid, AB InBev must persuade several crucial stakeholders, including Altria and the Santo Domingo family. 
The bank reckons AB InBev have taken the last three years to discuss its plans with stakeholders “to get them on board” and any reservations about “strategic intend” have now been removed. The stock closed the trading session at £36.35, up 46.5p, or 1.3pc. 
On the broader market, the FTSE 100 plunged into the red, wiping out Friday’s gains, falling 150.15 points, or 2.47pc, to 5,958.86, as further weak data from China and a bearish broker note dragged mining stocks lower. Profits earned by Chinese industrial companies declined at its sharpest rate in four years last month, official data showed. 
Mike McCudden, of Interactive Investor, said: “Investors returning to the market with a renewed sense of confidence have had their bubble burst once again as Chinese economic data continues to disappoint.” 
Mr McCudden also warned the FTSE could come under further pressure, as the International Monetary Fund prepares to cut its global growth forecast. 
Meanwhile, Jameel Ahmad, of FXTM, warned "crucial data" due to be released by both China and the US later in the week could "expose markets to further losses". 
International miner Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) became the biggest casualty of the day after Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) warned its equity value could “evaporate” , if commodity prices remain at current levels. Panic stricken investors offloaded the stock, as it hit another fresh low, plunging 28.6p, or 29.4pc, to 68.6p. 
Hunter Hillcoat, of Investec, expects commodity markets to remain “subdued” for several years to come, given the coincidence of excess supply and a slowdown in demand, particularly from China. If commodity prices do not recover, Mr Hillcoat reckons the value for Glencore and Anglo American (LSE: AAL.L - news ) equity holders is “virtually eliminated” given sustained depressed earnings. 
Anglo American slid 10.1pc to 552.7p, while BHP Billiton (NYSE: BBL - news ) was off by 6pc to 964.1p, Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) fell 4.8pc to £21.11 and Antofagasta (LSE: ANTO.L - news ) was 4.9pc lower at 481p. 
* Oil exporters face years of pain from tumbling prices, says IMF * Questor share tip: Is now the time to buy Glencore? 
Confirmation Vodafone and Liberty Global (NasdaqGS: LBTYA - news ) had ended early-stage discussions regarding asset swaps sent the mobile operator into the red. Robert Grindle, of Deutsche Bank (Other OTC: DBAGF - news ) , said he was pleased Vodafone had “not rushed” into another fixed deal, adding there may be an opportunity to exploit overlap with Liberty assets at a later date. Shares fell 4.8pc to 207.2p. 
Elsewhere, shares in ITV (LSE: ITV.L - news ) rallied 0.9pc to 250.5p amid talk that Liberty Global will now increase its 9.9pc stake in the broadcaster following the termination of talks with Vodafone. 
BAE Systems (LSE: BA.L - news ) was among the best performers after Bernstein upgraded the stock from “market perform” to “outperform”. The broker said the motivation for the move was based on improved expectations in international defence growth and an increased margin of safety in the current share price. The stock climbed 4.5p to 444.5p. 
Mid-cap stock Ultra Electronics (Other OTC: UEHPY - news ) was among the favourites after JPMorgan (LSE: JPIU.L - news ) Cazenove lifted its rating to “overweight” from “neutral” thanks to “green shoots of recovery” in western defence spending. David Perry, of JPMorgan Cazenove, said: “Western defence stocks are more attractive on a relative basis in a period of heightened economic uncertainty.” Shares leapt 25p to £16.84. 
Shares in Irish oil and gas exploration company Petroceltic inched 3.3pc higher to 61p after it was granted an injunction by the High Court of Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) preventing an extraordinary general meeting called by its largest shareholder Worldview Capital from going ahead. Worldview, which has a 29pc stake in the company, was due to put the resolution to the meeting, on Oct (HKSE: 3366-OL.HK - news ) 5, about Petroceltic’s announcement earlier this year that it will issue senior secured bonds. * Petroceltic's biggest shareholder calls for meeting to oust chief executive Finally, Aim-listed Flowgroup ticked 2.4pc higher to 10.5p after a stellar half-year sales growth of 28pc. However, the innovative energy company recorded an operating loss of £8.4m which analysts say was largely driven by investment in headcount in its energy division, in preparation for growth.
